Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2011 03:08AM Grazie47 wrote: I was diagnosed one week before flying to Texas for a family reunion, so I made the decision to not tell anyone other than my husband and my BFF.  I didn't want the reunion to be about me, I wanted to enjoy it just as it was planned.  My great niece had just gotten her hairdressers license so I had her cut my very long hair, that was the talk of the reunion and I secretly smiled knowing why I was cutting my hair.  My great niece didn't have much experience cutting long hair and really didn't want to screw it up, LOL if only she knew.  She did a great job, she got some experience and I had fun going through my first step of losing my hair. When we returned my husband didn't want to tell our sons, he didn't want them to worry. I told him they are adults and will be the first we will tell, they will not find out from someone else.  I agree with Survivor 11 to not tell them would create a distrust.  Everything I have been through, every test the first one I call are my sons, they know every little detail and freely discuss it with me and anyone else who is interested. I work in a very culturally diverse nursing home, I went into work and calmly stated that I have been diagnosed with breast cancer and would be taking a leave of absence.  Wow was I ever surprised everyone was so comforting and wishing me well.  While I was at home fighting this rotten disease I was overwhelmed with the support that I got from people other than my family.  I got flowers, gifts, cards, calls of support and more importantly prayers from every known religion, Christens, Jews, Muslims, Fundamentalists, Hindus, Buddists, all praying for my recovery. Some co workers would just call out of the blue to gossip, talk, wish me well or to just pray, it was very uplifting. My extended family was just a wonderful, I am blessed.

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2011 02:36AM Grazie47 wrote: As a mother I would be devastated that my child did not tell me, I am not a child I am his mother. The only way to keep a secret is to keep it to yourself, if not it will eventually come out, much better if she heard it from you and not someone else. I work with the elderly and they have incredible life experiences, they are way stronger then you think and extremely wise.   They are not children they are adults and deserve to be treated like adults. On the other hand my parents died when I was young so I don't have any experience sharing my diagnosis with them so I am only speaking as a mother. Good luck with you decision.
